title: Germany’s Jens Spahn challenges Europe to walk the walk
text:
BERLIN – Jens Spahn, one of a handful of conservative hopefuls vying to succeed Angela Merkel as chancellor, has a clear message for the incoming European Commission: Live up to the lofty rhetoric.

“Instead of just ‘we should do it’ speeches, it should be ‘we are doing it,’ less describing problems, more solving problems,” Spahn told POLITICO in an interview, adding he is confident that Commission President-elect Ursula von der Leyen would “bring about a change of thinking.”

Spahn, who is German health minister and a senior official in the center-right Christian Democrats (CDU), said that to win back the public’s trust, the EU must take action on issues ranging from health to migration and digitalization, warning that time is running out. The most recent Eurobarometer survey shows that while an increasing number of Europeans trust the EU, including in Germany, nearly half tend not to.

Describing von der Leyen, a party colleague with whom he served in Merkel’s Cabinet, as “fast, structured and ambitious,” Spahn said he expects her to upend the way the EU functions. Even as he was full of praise for his senior party colleague, Spahn's open challenge to von der Leyen's Commission betrayed his own ambition to help steer Europe's future.

“Europe needs ambition and ideas, but Europeans also want solutions that improve their everyday lives,” he said. “Finding the balance between vision and action is what politics is all about and Ursula von der Leyen can do that.”

A former state secretary in the finance ministry under Wolfgang Schäuble, Spahn is a leader of the CDU's conservative wing and a favorite of the party's younger members.

Though Spahn regularly comments on EU health issues and was active in the broader European debates during the European election campaign, his latest intervention offers a glimpse of his larger political horizon and comes just as his chances of becoming his party’s standard bearer in the next election have been rekindled.

In December, he lost a contest for the CDU leadership to Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, Merkel's top choice to succeed her as chancellor. Since then, Kramp-Karrenbauer’s fortunes have faded, with a series of missteps renewing doubts within the party over whether she would be a suitable candidate for chancellor.

In an effort to bolster Kramp-Karrenbauer’s standing, Merkel handed her the defense portfolio, which was previously held by von der Leyen. But with only 19 percent of Germans believing she can successfully lead the CDU, according to a poll published earlier this month, Kramp-Karrenbauer faces an uphill battle.

Health boost

Spahn, 39, has benefited from the shifting winds. As health minister, he has won support by addressing a shortage of caregivers and pushing legislation to increase the number of organ donors. This has bolstered Spahn’s public profile and he now ranks as one of the country’s most popular politicians, well ahead of Kramp-Karrenbauer.

A former state secretary in the finance ministry under Wolfgang Schäuble, Spahn is a leader of the CDU's conservative wing and a favorite of the party's younger members. But he also has a history of tension with Merkel, whose migration policies he criticized and blamed for the party's loss of support.

That history makes Spahn less appealing to the more moderate coalition of CDU members around Merkel who believe her brand of pragmatic centrism is the key to future success. Spahn also has a reputation for being exceptionally direct, even by German standards, a quality that hasn't endeared him to everyone.

At the same time, Spahn's steady rise in the party, which came despite Merkel's early efforts to block him, has convinced many of his leadership potential.

Even as he lost the leadership contest to Kramp-Karrenbauer, Spahn was tapped by many members as the man of the party's future.

Though Spahn isn’t the only potential challenger to Kramp-Karrenbauer — Armin Laschet, the state premier of North Rhine-Westphalia, and Friedrich Merz, another vanquished candidate for the CDU’s leadership last year, are also seen as contenders — his success in the health ministry has given him momentum.

The current government’s term doesn’t expire until the fall of 2021. However, disarray within the Social Democrats, the junior partner in Merkel’s “grand coalition,” has spurred speculation the government may collapse before then. The center-left party is in the midst of a leadership contest that could trigger its exit from the government.

"Something has to happen there, and fast. People have to feel that Europe is making a difference" — Jens Spahn, German health minister

Nonetheless, with a clear majority of Germans satisfied with the grand coalition and the SPD withering in the polls, making early elections risky, such an outcome remains unlikely.

That should give Spahn, who has stayed silent about whether he plans to pursue his party's nomination ahead of the next election, plenty of time to position himself.

For now, that means regularly doing the rounds on Germany's talk show circuit and prodding Europe on what he describes as the "great problem of migration."

"Something has to happen there, and fast," he said. "People have to feel that Europe is making a difference."

The CDU’s practice has been to put forth the party’s leader as its candidate for chancellor, hence the expectation that Kramp-Karrenbauer would follow Merkel. Yet there is no hard and fast rule.

If Kramp-Karrenbauer continues to lose ground and the CDU along with her (the Greens have pulled within striking distance of the conservatives in recent months), party tradition could follow Merkel out the door.
description: Up-and-coming German health minister urges his CDU colleague to upend the way Brussels works.
